byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Berlin, and Dan Bilefsky from London. Reporting was contributed by Palko Karasz from Budapest; Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva; Helene Bienvenu from Roszke, Hungary; and Aleksandar Dimishkovski from Skopje, Macedonia.
byline.original: By ALISON SMALE and DAN BILEFSKY

abstract: German government reports failure in talks with Hungary, Czech Republic, Slovakia and Poland aimed at approving joint European Union proposal to distribute migrants throughout EU member countries based on quota system; in face of resistance from Central European nations, officials in Berlin have raised possibility of a majority vote, rather than traditional consensus, to decide matter.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s foreign minister, during talks in Prague, failed to persuade Hungary and other central European partners to adopt a plan suggested this week by the European Union.

headline.main: Quota Proposal Fails to Gain Traction as Germany Prepares for More Arrivals
headline.print_headline: Quota Proposal Fails to Gain Traction as Germany Prepares for More Arrivals

snippet: Germany’s foreign minister, during talks in Prague, failed to persuade Hungary and other central European partners to adopt a plan suggested this week by the European Union.

keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
